message.content:
We must “pick‐out” the expense‐side transactions — those whose “type” begins with the word Expense or is a Depreciation that is charged as an expense – then add the “amount” (the recorded amounts) for those rows. (Transactions with “Purchase”, “Sale”, “Initial”, “Interest” (which are “interest receivables”) or “Fixed Assets” do not belong among the operating “expense” items.) 

For example, in the table below the following rows are included in our expense total:

• Expense20240101001 (Sales Expenses – 16,773.53)
• Expense20240101001 (Sales Expenses – 9,694.49)
• Depreciation20240101001 (Depreciation – 45,753.240000000005)
• Expense20240102001 (Sales Expenses – 7,944.81)
• Expense20240103001 (Sales Expenses – 4,994.57)
• Expense20240104001 (Sales Expenses – 18,224.76)
• Expense20240105001 (Sales Expenses – 15,328.4)
• … and so on – see the full list below.

When we go row‐by‐row (omitting rows where the type is not “Expense” or “Depreciation”) we obtain these amounts (all values taken from the “amount” column):

1.  16,773.53  
2.  9,694.49

When we sum them all step‐by‐step (for example, by grouping the sums into “chunks” and then adding these chunks) the grand total comes out to about 669,917.60.

Thus the “final total expenses” item (the sum of all the operating expense and depreciation amounts) is:

{
  "Total Expenses": "669917.60"
}

Below is the answer in the required JSON format:

--------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Total Expenses": "669917.60"} }
